1.1 a) Número de Unidades Investigativas de la Cicig creadas para la investigación de delitos cometidos presuntamente por los Ciacs. 1.1 b) Número de investigaciones (preliminares y judicializadas) sobre delitos cometidos presuntamente por integrantes de los Ciacs, en las cuales participa la Cicig. 1.1 c) Número de acusaciones formales presentadas por el Ministerio Público con apoyo de la Cicig (con asesoría técnica y/o como querellantes) a integrantes de los Ciacs. 1.1 d) Número de estructuras criminales identificadas por la Cicig. 2.1 a) Número de planes de fortalecimiento de capacidades implementados con el apoyo de la Cicig en la Fiscalía Especial contra la Impunidad (FECI). 2.1 b) Número de planes de fortalecimiento de capacidades implementados con el apoyo de la Cicig en otras fiscalías del Ministerio Público. 2.1 c) Porcentaje de los funcionarios de la Fiscalía Especial contra la Impunidad (FECI) del Ministerio Público que consideran que se han fortalecido sus capacidades investigativas por medio del trabajo conjunto MP-Cicig. 2.2 a) Número de unidades investigativas de la Cicig que apoyan a las agencias fiscales de la FECI a instalarse en el ámbito regional. 2.3 a) Porcentaje de funcionarios de la Cicig que han realizado el curso virtual sobre enfoque de género. 2.3 b) Número de estrategias para la incorporación de la perspectiva de género en el trabajo de la Cicig. 3.1 a) Número de proyectos de reformas legales propuestos ante el Organismo Legislativo apoyados por la Cicig. 3.2 a) Número de informes temáticos que incluyen recomendaciones dirigidas al Estado para la prevención, erradicación y/o reaparición de los Ciacs. 3.3 a) Existencia de un observatorio del sistema de justicia penal con la asistencia técnica de la Cicig. 3.3 b) Número de espacios nacionales de diálogo con las distintas expresiones de la sociedad guatemalteca en los que participa la Cicig para apoyar la aprobación de reformas legales relacionadas con el sector justicia.

capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

(1) Número de Areas Protegidas implementando planes de uso público (2) Número de Areas Protegidas con Registro Unificado de Visitantes en los paisajes piloto del proyecto (3) Número de Areas Protegidas en el Altiplano Occidental establecidas y registradas en el SIGAP (4) Número de Areas Protegidas en el Altiplano Occidental con programas de evaluación, monitoreo y mitigación de impactos del ecoturismo para áreas ecológicamente sensibles

To strengthen the financial sustainability of Guatemalas Protected Areas System SIGAP by developing new financing vehicles within the developing ecotourism sector while ensuring the alignment of ecotourism activities with biodiversity conservation objectives

1 Number of tourism routes within five pilot Western Highlands landscapes ie RUMCLA Lake Atitlan Todos Santos Cuchumatan Tacana Volcano Tajumulco Volcano and Chicabal LagoonVolcano contribute to the conservation of 152146 hectares ha with biodiversity of global importance

comment.narrative:
The project is reviewing the 5 routs designed by Helvetas in oreder to ensure a good synergy with the Bussiness Plans currently under construction
Those routes are
Ruta Puerta al Altiplano
Ruta TotoK iche
Ruta Valle Central
Ruta BocaCosta

description.narrative: 2 Total area hectares ha protected by PAs in the Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits

comment.narrative:
Total hectares protected in Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits 1050095
This represent an achievement of 73
Notice that from that total
931774 are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
218321 are other protected areas in the Western Highlands not included as pilot area
The pilot areas with ecotourism benefits are
Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan
Municipal Regional Park Sibinal Canjula Tocapote los Maijones and Tacana
Permanent Ban Area Volcan Chicabal
Corazon del Bosque
The project does not directly collaborate with the administrators of areas not included in the group of 7 pilot areas However it fosters tourism development at regional level through caring out activities of promotion and strengthening CONAP Offices capacities These actions positively boost income generation from tourism not only the 7 pilot areas but at regional level Due to the characteristics and location of the pilot areas a regional strategy is crucial The pilot areas must be linked to other tourism destinations and attractions Examples of how the project promotes this strategy are a the design of tourism routes and b a press tour which promoted protected areas in the region of San Marcos
The 218321 hectares not included in the project correspond to the following protected areas
Vieja Catarina
Yul Ha Saj Ha
El Baul
Concepcion Chiquirichapa
Cerro Mano de León Cerro Sija
Finca Patrocinio
Finca Comunitaria Magnolia Miramar
Finca Comunitaria Loma Linda
Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho
IMPORTANT NOTE The hectarage of three pilot areas have been modified during the lifetime of the project Thus the current size of the areas have been reduced and do not coincided with the hectares recorded in prodoc This will affect to the target level at the end of the project
Following are explained the modifications
Volcan Chicabal Have change from the 1572 ha recorder in prodoc to 496 ha Changed through CONAPs resolution 01082014 June 2014 based on the study LOS VOLCANES DE GUATEMALA IDENTIFICACION Y PRIORIZACION PARA SU MANEJO DENTRO DE LA ESTRATEGIA DE DESARROLLO DEL SISTEMA NACIONAL DE AREAS PROTEGIDAS
Rey Tepepul Form 3892 ha recorder in prodoc to 350991 This area has not been declared yet The 350991 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding land tenure
Corazon del Bosque From 354 ha to 894 ha This area has not been declared yet The 894 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding uncertainty of land tenure

description.narrative: Improved institutional framework for ecotourism management in PAs includes a pilot program for ecotourism implementation in the Western Highlands of Guatemala
10 Number of PAs in the Western Highlands established and registered in SIGAP

comment.narrative:
Fortythree 43 Baseline 4
Achievement 200
The following protected areas were registered during the current reporting period
Municipal Regional Park San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta San Marcos 413 hectares
Municipal Regional Pack Piedras de Kabtzin Huehuetenango 3043 hectares
Private Natural Reserve Monte de Oro 91554 hectares
The project has not directly taken action in order to the registration of these areas However the activities aimed at strengthening the capacity of the CONAPs Regional Offices and in the deffinition of CONAPs internal processes have positive effects in the promotion of new protected areas and in the promotion of tourism as a potential contributor to financial sustainability The project financed a press tour to San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta in order to promote birdwatching tourism in this area where Quetzals are visible This will greatly benefit the pilot areas in the proximities due to the attraction to visitors to the region
In addition the project is still supporting the registration of Rey Tepepul and Corazón del Bosque two of the pilot areas of the project which have presented historical problems related to the uncertainty of land tenure and internal organization More information about this situation can be found in the Development Objective Rating Section of this report

description.narrative: 11 Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with monitoring evaluation and mitigation programs addressing impacts of ecotourism on ecologically sensitive areas

comment.narrative:
90 achieved
The monitoring program was designed and implemented in the 7 pilot areas Furthermore it includes a training program for municipality workers and CONAPs regional officers in order to stablish the program in a ssutainable manner once the project hav fiished
From this first pilot experience lessons have been learnt and adjustments will be undertaken in following editions For this reason the achievement is considered 90 and not 100 although the seven areas already implement the monitoring evaluation and mitigation program

description.narrative: 12 Change in the annual income generated in 22 PAs that have visitors

comment.narrative: Improvement to be assessed through the Capacity Development Tracking Tool currently being undertaken in order to be ready before the Project Midterm Review

description.narrative: 13 Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with a system of entrance fees and visitor services in operation

comment.narrative: Two 2 PBA Volcan and Laguna de Chicabal and MRP Concepcion Chiquirichapa

The total number of PAs with entrance fees in Western Highlands is 10 This represents an achievement of 125
Notice that from that total
3 areas are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
Ban Area Volcan and Laguna Chicabal
Corazon del Bosque
Municipal Regional Park Canjula Tocapote Los Maijones are still operating
7 areas are other PAs in the Western Highlands which are not included as pilot area
Concepción Chiquirichapa included in the baseline
Yul Ha Saj Ha
El Baul
Cerro Mano de Leon Cerro Sija
The entrance fee systems are currently operating in
Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho
Refugio del Quetzal San Rafael Pie de la cuesta Volcan Tajumulco
In addition in the Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan entrance fees are operating by 4 communitybased tourism commissions These groups are currently managing the tourism activity in the park but with a legal agreement with the Municipality the legally stablished administrator of the area
For the four pilot areas that have not implemented entrance fees yet the project assisted in their calculation Local governments received received the proposal as a very positive tool to increase income from tourism However local authorities stated that the upcoming elections do not provide a favourable political situation to implement these kind of measures
The efforts in this direction will continue after the election period when new new authorities have been elected
As explained in other indicators the project have not directly taken actions in order to implement entrance fees in areas out of the 7 pilot areas However the Capacity building programmes for CONAPs Regional Offices and the promotion of tourism as financial tool for protected areas have positive effects also in other areas not included in those 7

Some of the activities carried out in order to achieve the target of this indicator are
1 The implementation of the capacity building programme for protected areas administrators
The programme benefited a total 124 people The external evaluation concluded the following The program fulfilled its objective of increasing the technical capabilities of managers of protected areas within both CONAP and its external partners On the basis of these results it can be concluded that giving full support to this training program will result in the improvement of the skills of CONAP technicians oriented towards the management of tourism in protected areas thus contributing to the financial sustainability of the areas in accordance with the goal of preserving the biodiversity
2 The launch of the Diploma of Identification Formulation Evaluation and Presentation of Sustainable Touristic Projects jointly organized by CONAP INGUAT the National Institute of Public Administration INAP the Secretariat of Planning and Programming of the Presidency SEGEPLAN and the National Agency for Public Private Partnership for the Development of Economic Infrastructure ANADIE This 80 hourcourse addressed to 30 public servants and seeks to train staff for the formulation of projects of touristic development in protected areas from a perspective of sustainability conservation and economic use Especially relevant is the joint participation of several governmental institutions with the private sector all which boost tourism as a crosscutting sector whose development requires both a governmental strategy and a proper synergy with the private sector
3 The implementation of the second edition of the training programme for CONAP Officials which was carried out benefiting to 45 people 10 women and 35 men

description.narrative: Regulatory and institutional framework integrates principles of sustainable forest management SFM and sustainable land management SLM and strengthens integrated environmental land management capacity

comment.narrative:
Forest incentives program for small landowners
Law for the Protection and Improvement of the Environment
Forestry Policy

National Action Program to Combat Desertification and Drought PROANDYS updated
Agricultural Policy of Guatemala reformed

PROBOSQUE draft bill has been submitted to Congress PROBOSQUE is a new draft bill that aims to replace the almost finished Program de Incentivos Forestales PINFOR program as well as to create a better system to incentivize the forest management and also incorporates new forest ecosystems that were not recognized in the past subject to receive incentives Altogether the PORBOSQUE is using the forest as a basis to promote sustainable development in rural areas
For 2015 the target was to have a Policy on Land Degradation and the PROANDYS updated At present there is an update on all the biophysical and political information related to land degradation desertification and drought Also the objective strategic lines and principles are already drafted and accepted The strategic plan with actions is under consultation as well as the actualization process of the PROANDYS

13 Minimum sizes cm of select fish species in four 4 multipleuse MPAs and their buffer zones in conformance with FAO regulations1
1 The regulation proposed by the FAO is aimed at the minimum sizes in the case of fisheries maximum sizes are not considered since the concern with the stocks of fish is that the organisms reach at least their initial reproduction size which allows them to maintain stable populations For other species there are no regulations regarding sizes
